bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 31, 1908

div1.p: Gorgas sends Kean results of experiments on Phinotas Oil in exterminating mosquitoes. He encloses two letters from Joseph A. LePrince. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collection Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 31, 1908
div1.opener:
From Col Gorgas.
Referring to your File No.
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
DEPARTMENT OF SANITATION
ANCON CANAL ZONE
COL. W. C. GORGAS. U. S. A.,
CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER.
In replying refer to file No. 1097/6
Ancon, C. Z., July 31, 1908.
Major Jefferson R. Kean,
Medical Corps, United States Army,
Sanitary Department, Havana, Cuba.
My dear Kean:-
div1.p:
I find yours of June 2nd on my return from leave, and
inclose you two letters enclosure 1 enclosure 2 from Mr. LePrince with regard to the use
of Phinotas Oil, and also. rReports of Dr. Smith, the Entomologist
of the State of New Jersey, on the same subject have guided us.. We use a good
deal of it down here, as under many conditions we find it better
and cheaper than the crude oil. I do not believe it would be
useful under any circumstances, for stegomyia work. Most of our
work down here now is anopheles.

Will you ask Captain Fortin to get me 100 cigars like
the last, and send to me by mail? Will you kindly be good
enough to pay for them, postage, etc., and send me bill. I have
forgotten just what the last bill was.

I got back from my leave in the United States two weeks
ago. Am head-over-heels in work making up for lost time. I have
had considerable trouble down here in managing my affairs for the
past year. They all seem to be amicably settled now, and things
are flowing along very pleasantly. I will tell you more about
Major J. R. Kean, #2.
it some of these days when I have a little more leisure for writing.

I saw a rumor in the paper some two weeks ago of yellow fever
originating in Havana, but as I have seen no confirmation of this I
take it that it was merely rumor. At any rate, I sincerely hope it is.
Nobody knows better than I do, the sea-sick feeling at the pit of the
stomach that the sanitary officer has at the report of a new case of
yellow fever, when he thinks he has everything of this kind satis-
factorily settled.

Mrs. Gorgas is back with me, and in very good health.
Aileen stayed behind for a visit at Leavenworth.

Phillips and Lyster are never seen in public now at all;
both spend all their time on examination papers. I was very much
surprised to hear in Washington of the men who failed in the examina-
tion. Carter I knew personally, and always thought a very good man.
Gibson I had always heard spoken of as a good man.

Please remember me most cordially to Mrs. Kean, and believe
me, as ever
